hints.content: Let's think about each statement to see whether it is true.

###Each shaded number has a multiple of $4$ in the ones place.

The one-digit multiples of $4$ are $0$, $4$, and $8$.

The number $12$ is shaded, but it has a $2$ in the ones place.

This statement is *not* true.

###If we add $10$ to a shaded number, we get another number from the pattern.

$4\maroonD{+10}=14$

The number $4$ is shaded, but $14$ is not shaded.

This statement is *not* true.

###To get to the next shaded number, add $4$.

$\begin{align}
0 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 4\\\\
4 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 8\\\\
8 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 12\\\\
12 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 16\\\\
16 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 20\\\\
20 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 24\\\\
24 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 28\\\\
28 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 32\\\\
32 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 36\\\\
36 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 40\\\\
40 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 44\\\\
44 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 48\\\\
48 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 52\\\\
52 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 56\\\\
56 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 60\\\\
60 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 64\\\\
64 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 68\\\\
68 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 72\\\\
72 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 76\\\\
76 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 80\\\\
80 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 84\\\\
84 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 88\\\\
88 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 92\\\\
92 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 96\\\\
96 \goldE{+ 4} &\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 100
\end{align}$

This statement is true.

This statement is true:

- To get to the next shaded number, add $4$.
